reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s “value as product of relatively independent factors” model used to motivate eutopian fragility and the intuition that high-dimensionality pushes most probability mass toward low overall value. That model is an important support for the broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion, but not strictly necessary since the essay also argues fussiness via population ethics, digital minds, bounded/unbounded value functions, fat tails, and bads-vs-goods aggregation. So centrality is moderate.

On strength: the critique plausibly shows the toy model’s independence assumption is non-trivial and may be wrong in sign: real-world governance/AI optimization could induce strong correlations and attractor basins, meaning the distribution of outcomes might concentrate rather than “wash out” into low-product tails. That substantially weakens the toy-model-based quantitative intuition and the claim that “many dimensions” generically implies rarity of mostly-great futures. However, it doesn’t show correlations would in fact make mostly-great futures common; correlations could also worsen outcomes, and the essay’s core claim is about narrowness of near-best outcomes across moral views, which can remain true even under coupling. Hence only moderate refutation of a moderately central support.

Correctness is high: it is true that independence is an assumption; in complex systems many factors share substrates and can be correlated; and correlation structure can change tail mass and create attractors. The critique overstates slightly by implying the essay’s conclusion could be “directionally wrong” in general, since coupling doesn’t imply more mass near high value, but this is framed as a conditional possibility.

Clarity is high: the objection is specific (hidden coupling undermines independence/product intuition) and the claimed consequence is stated. Dead weight is minimal. It is essentially a single issue.

Overall: as a philosophical/technical objection it’s insightful and well-aimed at one argumentative lever, but it only moderately undercuts the overall thesis given the essay’s multiple independent routes to “no easy eutopia,” so the overall score is below the strength×centrality anchor.
title: Mechanistic coupling between moral dimensions creates attractor basins the independence model ignores
